titleStmt.author: Schroedl, Gerald F.

bibl.title: [Photograph of the Fort Marr Blockhouse in Benton, Tennessee] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl]
bibl.author: Schroedl, Gerald F.
bibl.note: This photograph is of the Fort Marr Blockhouse located at Benton in Polk County, Tennessee. Fort Marr, also known as 'The Old Fort,' was constructed around 1814 near Old Fort, Tennessee. The fort was positioned along the Old Federal Road and housed troops who were assigned to protect white travelers using the road and the Cherokees from Creek retaliation. The fort was also said to have been used to safeguard supplies and as a campsite for soldiers in transit during the Creek War of 1814-1815. The name Fort Marr was established when the fort was renovated into a stockade to use during the removal of the Cherokee people to the west. It is believed that the fort was named after George Washington Lent Marr, who served under Andrew Jackson during the War of 1812 and the campaign of 1813-1814. After being relocated times since its construction, it was moved to its present location at Benton in 1965. In 1980, Fort Marr became the property of the Conservation Department of the state of Tennessee to be maintained and used as a historic site.

projectDesc.p: Prepared for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

figure.figDesc: This is a photographic image of the Fort Marr Blockhouse located in Benton, Tennessee. Photograph by Gerald F. Schroedl. This information was provided by the Frank H. McClung Museum.

p.note: This document consists of one image only.
